nodes.bodyText: What is the reason for introducing this abstract class? Is there any plan for having multiple classes extending it? Why don't you just simply add the necessary changes to the AlterTableAddConstraintAnalyzer?
That is just to be consistent with how it's done in other similar classes.
In other cases there are abstract classes because there are multiple classes extending them, and the common parts are moved to their abstract ancestor. Here there is no reason to do that.

I created a separate ticket for advancing the write ID during drop Constraint -> https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/HIVE-24513 .  I have changed the abstract class name to "AbstractConstraintAnalyzer". AbstractDropConstraintAnalyzer would also have to extend it.
Can we add the test for unique and check constraints as well for completeness?
Added unique and check constraints. Please review.
No need to modify the indentation of this annotation
According to the Hive checkstyle, the max line length is 120, please format the code according to that.
Don't see any line more than 90 in this class.
True, but I don't see the reason for this very change here, where you broke a line that was not longer than 120
My formatter uses 90. Will undo this change.
As this class will be extended by both the add and drop constraint analyzer, it should be in the org.apache.hadoop.hive.ql.ddl.table.constraint package.

nodes.bodyText: Actually I don't see anything constraint specific in this class. I'd suggest to just add the ddlDescWithWriteId and it's getter and setter to the AbstractAlterTableAnalyzer.
No need for that, AbstractAlterTableAnalyzer extends AbstractBaseAlterTableAnalyzer which already has the very same thing in it.
So in conclusion I don't think that you need this class at all, just call setAcidDdlDesc at the end of the analyzeCommand in AlterTableAddConstraintAnalyzer, if it is a transactional table.
